Though they are quick to forgive their master's rudeness and indiscretions (as well as the behavior of their master's allies), the wizmos will leave and never return if their master or their allies attack them.

trait.name: Scram
entries: Opportunity attacks against the mob have disadvantage.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The mob can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the mob can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny wizmo. The mob can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Hijinks
entries: The mob pulls a prank, affecting each creature it can see within 5 feet, which must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature has disadvantage on the next attack roll or ability check it makes before the end of its turn.

action.name: Slams
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target in the mob's space. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) bludgeoning damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage if the mob has half its hit points or fewer. If the mob is formed into a Super Wizmo, this attack deals an additional 9 ({@damage 2d8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Super Wizmo (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, by standing on each other's shoulders and acting in perfect coordination, the mob can emulate the form of a single unified Small sized creature, with roughly the proportions of a wizmo. While in this form, the mob loses the benefit of its Swarm trait, but deals an additional {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage with its slams.

reaction.name: Swipe
entries: When the mob takes damage from a creature within 5 feet of it, the mob steals one item the creature is carrying that isn't armor being worn or a weapon being carried.

When a wrothian creation matrix is flush with biomass and fully powered, it leaves no imperfections in its creations; however, when short on time or materials, it sometimes creates outright abominations. Wrothian failures are the genetic outcasts left over when this process goes horribly wrong, resulting in hideous beast-like creatures which scramble about on four legs and hunger for fresh meat.

Instead of exterminating these creatures, the primarchs have chosen to utilize them, releasing them as expendable shock troopers during their raids. Indeed, because they require so little biomass to create, the primarchs will sometimes create a pack of failures specifically to wreak havoc as they reap more populous settlements.

entries.name: Wroth
entries: Across the galaxy, these words are spoken in whispers, with fearful glances to the night sky:

"Beware the wroth, that scourge, that utter evil that dwells in the Black. For by night, they descend in their stygian ships to steal away children, to slaughter entire villages, to desecrate our lands, only to vanish before sunrise."

entries.name: Takers from the Black
entries: Few understand anything truly concrete about the wroth, save for the terror of their enigmatic machines, their unrestrained cruelty, and their appetite for stealing away intelligent beings. Wrothian ships are powerful, though not unassailable; however, their raids rarely meet organized resistance. Once the wroth land, they converge on a settlement with a force of takers and collector vats, overseen by a wrothian alpha or a primarch, and begin stealing away as many humanoids as possible. Then, they vanish just as quickly as they arrived, retreating untraceably with their prisoners into the Black. No one taken ever returns.

entries.name: The Perfect
entries: Wrothians consider themselves the pinnacle of life in the universe, for constructing even a single wrothian taker requires the sacrifice of hundreds of lesser humanoid lives; constructing a primarch requires thousands. For this reason, wrothians believe themselves to be perfect—no other lifeform is comparable. Whereas other races wither and die with age, the wroth live indefinitely. Whereas other races have feeble minds, wrothian primarchs possess vast intellects and psionic power. Whereas other races rely on the crutch of green planets and their resources, the wroth persist in the endless Black.

The fuel of their grim life cycle begins at processing other organisms. When they land to abduct humanoids, the captives are thrust into collector vats, where their skin, muscle, and bones are gradually but methodically digested into a rich ooze of bio-matter. The brains and nerves are horrifically untouched by this process, and are instead preserved in jars, to be tormented indefinitely for psionic power. The bio-matter of hundreds or thousands is returned to the ship, where an advanced creation matrix weaves together the molecules of a new, perfect organism.

These details, as well as the fact that wrothians are nourished by the constant hum of psionic energy on their ships, is wholly unknown to most. The vast majority of the galaxy only understands the horrors of wrothian arrival and the loss felt by those taken.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The failure has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the failure moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the failure can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is Large or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}). Until this grapple ends, the failure can't bite another target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

Wrothian takers are bred by the dozen to scour planets for new captives, and are as vicious as they are clever. Deep in their minds, they contain the spark of psionic potential, but sadly, their creation falls short; only the primarchs are truly perfect. Takers violently rip through settlements, capturing the weak and delivering them to collection pods. If a taker lives to its life's potential, it harvests enough humanoids to create a single primarch.

entries.name: Wroth
entries: Across the galaxy, these words are spoken in whispers, with fearful glances to the night sky:

"Beware the wroth, that scourge, that utter evil that dwells in the Black. For by night, they descend in their stygian ships to steal away children, to slaughter entire villages, to desecrate our lands, only to vanish before sunrise."

entries.name: Takers from the Black
entries: Few understand anything truly concrete about the wroth, save for the terror of their enigmatic machines, their unrestrained cruelty, and their appetite for stealing away intelligent beings. Wrothian ships are powerful, though not unassailable; however, their raids rarely meet organized resistance. Once the wroth land, they converge on a settlement with a force of takers and collector vats, overseen by a wrothian alpha or a primarch, and begin stealing away as many humanoids as possible. Then, they vanish just as quickly as they arrived, retreating untraceably with their prisoners into the Black. No one taken ever returns.

entries.name: The Perfect
entries: Wrothians consider themselves the pinnacle of life in the universe, for constructing even a single wrothian taker requires the sacrifice of hundreds of lesser humanoid lives; constructing a primarch requires thousands. For this reason, wrothians believe themselves to be perfect—no other lifeform is comparable. Whereas other races wither and die with age, the wroth live indefinitely. Whereas other races have feeble minds, wrothian primarchs possess vast intellects and psionic power. Whereas other races rely on the crutch of green planets and their resources, the wroth persist in the endless Black.

The fuel of their grim life cycle begins at processing other organisms. When they land to abduct humanoids, the captives are thrust into collector vats, where their skin, muscle, and bones are gradually but methodically digested into a rich ooze of bio-matter. The brains and nerves are horrifically untouched by this process, and are instead preserved in jars, to be tormented indefinitely for psionic power. The bio-matter of hundreds or thousands is returned to the ship, where an advanced creation matrix weaves together the molecules of a new, perfect organism.

These details, as well as the fact that wrothians are nourished by the constant hum of psionic energy on their ships, is wholly unknown to most. The vast majority of the galaxy only understands the horrors of wrothian arrival and the loss felt by those taken.

trait.name: Psionic Lash
entries: When the taker hits a creature with a melee attack, it deals an additional 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The taker makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) slashing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Crystalline Rod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) force damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Wrothian Blaster
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Neural Lock
entries: One creature of the taker's choice within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Created to oversee raids in the primarchs' stead, the wrothian alphas are larger, more aggressive versions of takers, which stand nearly a foot taller and wield substantial psionic power. Alphas are still strictly second to the primarchs in all respects, but are allowed a degree of free thought that takers are rarely afforded. Such independence is necessary to strategize offworld, of course, but also ensures that alphas pledge their undying loyalty to the primarchs by choice, rather than by psionic demand.

entries: Across the galaxy, these words are spoken in whispers, with fearful glances to the night sky:

"Beware the wroth, that scourge, that utter evil that dwells in the Black. For by night, they descend in their stygian ships to steal away children, to slaughter entire villages, to desecrate our lands, only to vanish before sunrise."

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The alpha's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Psionic Lash
entries: When the alpha hits a creature with a melee attack, it deals an additional 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The alpha makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) slashing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Crystalline Rod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) force damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Wrothian Blaster
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Neural Lock
entries: One creature of the alpha's choice within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Vile, scheming, and wholly malevolent, wrothian primarchs are formidable psions of unmatched strength. They possess a vast but cryptic intellect of mysterious motivations and complex schemes which drives their every action. At a primarch's word, their ships descend from the Black upon undefended worlds and prisoners are taken to fuel their dark ambitions. Only in dire times do primarchs venture to the surface to command their forces directly; their psionic link is strong enough to possess their takers and failures from hundreds of miles away.

entries.name: Wroth
entries: Across the galaxy, these words are spoken in whispers, with fearful glances to the night sky:

"Beware the wroth, that scourge, that utter evil that dwells in the Black. For by night, they descend in their stygian ships to steal away children, to slaughter entire villages, to desecrate our lands, only to vanish before sunrise."

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The primarch's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Direct Control
entries: The primarch can use a bonus action to gain or relinquish control over a wrothian taker or wrothian failure within the range of its telepathy as if the primarch had targeted it with a dominate monster spell. This connection ends if the primarch or its target drops to 0 hit points, the primarch or its target are on different planes of existence, or the primarch chooses to end the connection. The primarch can only directly control one creature at a time.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Discognition
entries: One creature that the primarch can see within 60 feet completely forgets the events of the last minute. Additionally, as the target comes to grips with its senses, it has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Psionic Vice
entries: One creature that the primarch can see within 60 feet must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) psychic damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.

If a humanoid target drops to 0 hit points, it rises 1 round later as a zombie under the primarch's control, unless the humanoid is first restored to life or its body is destroyed. The primarch can have no more than twelve zombies under its control at one time.

Living symbiotically alongside psi-worms wherever they are found is a species of massive, magenta fungus known as xenobloom. The fungus forms dense, thorny forests and quickly grows back when cut down, so it presents a fearsome barrier to colonists and a thriving home to psi-worms. Consequently, settlements established on xenobloom-infested planets are typically built in areas where the fungus is most sparse, though this does little to stave off the fungi's ire in the long term.

entries.name: Worm Shelters
entries: Xenoblooms provide more than just physical shelter to psi-worms: they are also excellent hiding places. It isn't uncommon for humanoids trespassing in xenobloom-dominated regions to be ambushed by swarms of worms, from which only the most vigilant explorers tend to return.

entries.name: Psionic Fungus
entries: Xenoblooms also appear to be sentient, capable of defending themselves with lashing tendrils and engaging in sudden, explosive growth spurts to engulf would-be attackers.

Although the fungus has no psionic powers of its own, it has been observed to emit a psionic field that augments the powers of nearby psi-worms. It has been suggested that the xenoblooms form a planet-spanning psychic network that enables the psi-worms to communicate with each other, though the implications of such a thing are surely too terrifying to contemplate.

trait.name: Psionic Synapse
entries: Any creature or swarm within 30 feet of the xenobloom with the ability to cast spells psionically has advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

trait.name: Secure Roots
entries: The xenobloom has advantage on saving throws against spells or effects that would subject it to involuntary movement.

trait.name: Thicket
entries: The xenobloom counts as an area of natural difficult terrain; creatures can move through and end their turn in any space occupied by the xenobloom. However, any creature that ends its turn wholly or partly inside the xenobloom takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) slashing damage and must make a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} until the end of its next turn. Tiny creatures and swarms of Tiny creatures are immune to this effect.

action.name: Thorn Lash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Grow {@recharge 3}
entries: The xenobloom increases its size category by one step, as long as it is Huge or smaller. When it does so, its current and maximum hit points increase by 16 and it chooses which spaces to expand into. Any creatures in those spaces must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw or be immediately subjected to the xenobloom's Thicket ability. On a success, a creature is shunted into the nearest unoccupied space; a creature can voluntarily choose to fail this save.

reaction.name: Split
entries: When a Large or larger xenobloom takes slashing damage, it can use its reaction to split into two independent xenoblooms. The new xenoblooms are both one size category smaller than the original, and have half of its current hit points, rounded down.

The avia-ra hold a dizzying array of warrior-clergymen within their Congregation warfleet, from lowly shepherds which evangelize on far-off worlds, to mighty and eminent bishops which command the armada. But the rank of apologist is apart from the rest. Only specially- appointed avia-ra of great faith can take on the mantle of apologist, from which position they answer only to the Archbishops of the Sun. Though they are tasked with spreading the word of the Sun Above, as all avia-ra clergy are, apologists are also commanded to stifle darkness and suppress heresy, even within their own ranks. Their names are spoken of in frightful whispers by those who have turned their backs on the Sun Above.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The apologist is an 8th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Divine Strike
entries: Once on each of the apologist's turns when it hits a creature with a weapon attack, the apologist can cause the attack to deal an extra 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage to the target.

trait.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While the apologist is wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, its AC equals 10 plus its Dexterity modifier + its Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The apologist makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Avia-Ra Sunstaff (Ranged)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Avia-Ra Sunstaff (Melee)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

{@skill Technology|DarkMatter} Amoeboid mawkeepers maintain various positions on their maws, each overseeing or maintaining a specific function of the station. As a matter of course, mawkeepers are trained in the use of spells and are educated the intricacies of magical technology. If a threat should arise and the Sepulcher Knights falter, these mawkeepers are well-equipped to defend their stations.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mawkeeper is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The amoeboid can compress its body enough to squeeze through a 1-inch wide space.

action.name: Arc Baton
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage, and the target can't take reactions until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.

action.name: Flexible Form
entries: The amoeboid stretches, compresses, or molds its body into a static form of its choice that is no larger than 8 feet in any dimension. It can replicate something's basic shape, but not its color, texture, moving parts, or fine details. The amoeboid can't change its body's volume, nor can it move, attack, or cast spells while transformed into a static shape.

Alternatively, the amoeboid can touch a creature and assume its general form. Its size and other statistics don't change, but it gains the ability to speak and understand that creature's language, and if the target has a burrowing, climbing, or swimming speed, the amoeboid gains those with the same speed, up to a maximum of 40 feet.
The amoeboid can end a transformation on its turn (no action required). If transformed into a creature, it can only take actions that creature would be able to take.

reaction.name: Reform
entries: When the amoeboid takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from a nonmagical source and doesn't drop to 0 hit points, it can immediately regain {@dice 1d4} hit points, up to a maximum of the amount of damage taken.

Functionaries, politicians, and bankers are all bureaucrats, part of the growing market of middlemen which keep the 'verse's economy ticking. Uniformly, they lack the useful skills of an adventurer, and so have no means to defend themselves or survive on an undeveloped planet, but nonetheless consider themselves important and vital to their respective stations.

action.name: Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.

When a Coalition marine displays great promise to their superiors, they can be promoted to a squad leadership rank. These Coalition captains are given extra training and improved gear befitting their new roles. Though they are hardly ever seen without a squad of marines nearby, they are extremely dangerous opponents in their own right.

trait.name: Close Quarters Combat
entries: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on the captain's ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Impulse Pack
entries: When the captain uses its flight speed, it must begin and end its movement on the ground, otherwise it falls.

trait.name: Life Support Systems
entries: The captain wears an impulse frame, which counts as a life suit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The captain makes three ranged attacks or three melee attacks.

action.name: Antimatter Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Concussion Grenade
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) thunder damage and the target is {@condition deafened} until the beginning of the captain's next turn. Additionally, each creature within 10 feet of the target must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or also take this damage and be {@condition deafened} for the same duration.

action.name: Concussion Rifle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) thunder damage. The captain has disadvantage on attacks with this weapon if the target is within 20 feet.

action.name: Impactor Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d10}) radiant damage, or 13 ({@damage 2d12}) radiant damage if the target is within 15 feet of the captain. The impactor then overheats, and can't be used until the end of the captain's next turn.

action.name: Repeater
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

reaction.name: Heavy Frame
entries: When the captain takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from a nonmagical source, it can halve the damage taken.

Coalition marines are trained in fast-paced, hit-and-run combat using their impulse frames and close quarters weaponry to strike targets hard, fast, and without warning. Their frames allow them to operate comfortably in any environment, from frigid, airless moons, to scorching desert planets.

trait.name: Close Quarters Combat
entries: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on the marine's ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Impulse Pack
entries: When the marine uses its flight speed, it must begin and end its movement on the ground, otherwise it falls.

trait.name: Life Support Systems
entries: The marine wears an impulse frame, which counts as a life suit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The marine makes two ranged attacks, two melee attacks, or four attacks with its standard carbine with disadvantage.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Concussion Grenade
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) thunder damage and the target is {@condition deafened} until the beginning of the marine's next turn. Additionally, each creature within 10 feet of the target must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or also take this damage and be {@condition deafened} for the same duration.

action.name: Ion Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage, or 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage if the target is within 15 feet.

action.name: Standard Carbine
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

Firm contractors can perform a variety of duties, from infiltration and hacking, to accounting and negotiations. In a pinch, however, a contractor is a deadly combatant, capable of expertly (and discreetly) dispatching foes.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: The contractor has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The contractor deals an extra 14 ({@damage 4d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the contractor that isn't incapacitated and the contractor doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The contractor makes two attacks.

action.name: Antimatter Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Gnomish Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) force damage.

Gifted inventors and engineers, gadgeteers are always pushing the boundaries of what can be accomplished with magical technology. They are almost always festooned with hardware components, useful gadgets, and tricked- out blasters, as well as accompanied by an AI, or some other mechanical companion, which assists them in every endeavor.

trait.name: AI Companion
entries: If the gadgeteer rolls less than 16 with any of its listed skills, it treats the result as a 16 instead.

trait.name: Overcharge
entries: A blaster deals three extra dice of its damage and its Intelligence modifier when the gadgeteer hits with it (included in the attack).

action.name: Wrenchinator
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Concussion Rifle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 5d8 + 4}) thunder damage. The gadgeteer has disadvantage on attacks with this weapon if the target is within 20 feet.

action.name: Repeater
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 5d6 + 4}) radiant damage.

action.name: Omni-Grenade
entries: The gadgeteer throws a grenade at a point it can see within 30 feet. Each creature within a 5-foot radius of that point must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 5d8}) fire damage, or half as much on a successful save.

action.name: Gadget
entries: The gadgeteer uses one of the following gadgets:

items.name: Blink Button
entries: The gadgeteer teleports up to 15 feet.

items.name: Cloaking Device {@recharge 4}
entries: The gadgeteer becomes {@condition invisible} until the end of its next turn, as per the spell {@spell invisibility}.

items.name: Overheat Beacon {@recharge 5}
entries: Each blaster within 60 feet of the gadgeteer (excluding those carried by the gadgeteer) overheat until the end of the gadgeteer's next turn.

items.name: Shrink Ray
entries: One creature within 30 feet is targeted by the Reduce effect of the enlarge/reduce spell (save {@dc 14})

Hegemony troopers are the backbone of the Hegemony of Man's military. Outfitted with high-quality tactical gear and trained in all manner of combat, these troopers fill a variety of roles, from foot soldiers on the battlefield, to military police on human worlds.

trait.name: Comm Link
entries: The trooper is in constant communication and coordination with its allies within 2 miles of it. It can't be surprised by any creature or object that any of its allies within range are aware of.

trait.name: Life Suit
entries: The trooper's armor contains an integrated life suit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The trooper makes two attacks with its standard carbine, two attacks with its arc baton, or four attacks with its standard carbine with disadvantage.

action.name: Arc Baton
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) lightning damage. If the target is a creature, it can't take reactions until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Concussion Grenade
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) thunder damage and the target is {@condition deafened} until the beginning of the trooper's next turn. Additionally, each creature within 10 feet of the target must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or also take this damage and be {@condition deafened} for the same duration.

action.name: Standard Carbine
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

Lakshay oni are elite battle frame pilots of the Lakshay defense force who can single-handedly count a hundred or more kills in their tenure. While they usually pilot Lakshayan battle frames, they also make formidable opponents when on foot, wielding their signature katanas and swarm pistols for fast and lethal strikes. Oni are outfitted with cloaked armor, which changes color and texture with their environment.

trait.name: Alpha Strike
entries: If the oni is not surprised, it has advantage on initiative rolls.

trait.name: Cloaked Armor
entries: If the oni moves 10 feet or less on its turn, it has advantage on Stealth checks for that turn. Additionally, it can take the Hide action while in lightly obscured conditions.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The oni makes two attacks with its katana, three attacks with its swarm pistols, or six attacks with its swarm pistols with disadvantage.

action.name: Katana
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Swarm Pistols
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The oni adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the oni must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Nothing is more critical to the nautilids than finding a source of naturally-occurring Poseidon Solution; their entire population depends on it. While many nautilids prefer to stay aboard their whorl ships, nearly all become seekers for a time, especially in their youth. Seekers comb the galaxy, meticulously searching undiscovered systems for ocean-bearing planets and hoping to find one that would become New Poseidon. With any luck, a seeker might discover some new technology to aid the search or uncover a new clue to bring their race closer to a permanent answer.

trait.name: Aqua Suit
entries: The seeker wears an aqua suit, which counts as a life suit and provides the seeker with the benefits of a {@item universal translator|darkmatter}.

action.name: Rocket Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Ion Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage, or 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage if the target is within 15 feet.

Whether they fly giant starliners or nimble fighters, most pilots are experts in the operation of a variety of spaceships. What they lack in combat prowess, they make up for in their ability to skillfully maneuver through the Black.

trait.name: Ace Pilot
entries: When the pilot is in the Pilot role of a ship and takes Evasive Maneuvers, it can move 1,000 feet in any direction instead of 500 feet.

trait.name: Tricky Maneuver (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the pilot can gain advantage on a single Dexterity (Piloting) check or Dexterity saving throw it makes while in the Pilot role.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Repeater
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 60/240 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) obrażeń od promieniowania.

Every sizable starship is staffed with a number of useful, but ultimately expendable crewmen, redshirts. When danger arises, the hope is that these personnel (in their characteristic red shirts) will suffer casualties, while the ship's officers remain unscathed.

action.name: Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.

Clad in their platinum armor and wielding their signature energy swords, sepulcher knights are dedicated to maintaining the neutrality of the maws and the stability of the 'verse as a whole. None can stand before a band of sepulcher knights and expect to be victorious, for the knights command a sliver of power from the sepulcher star, which they believe is bequeathed unto their order by Old Un himself.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Sepulcher knight is an 8th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following paladin spells prepared:

trait.name: Divine Smite
entries: When the sepulcher knight hits a creature with a weapon attack, it can expend one spell slot to deal radiant damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The extra damage is {@dice 2d8} for a 1st-level spell slot, or {@dice 3d8} for a 2nd-level spell slot. The damage increases by {@dice 1d8} if the target is an undead or a fiend.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The sepulcher knight has an energy shield bracer.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sepulcher knight makes two attacks.

action.name: Laser Sword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) radiant damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) radiant damage if wielded with two hands.

action.name: Gamma Blade
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) force damage.

action.name: Repeater
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

Though skathári loathe magical technology in all its forms, they are nonetheless itinerant in nature, seeking out new worlds (even greatly inhospitable ones) for their clans to settle. On their migrations to new worlds, skathári nomads often wander, trusting the energies of the 'verse and their mysterious tree-goddess to guide them to their destinations. Whenever one encounters a skathári on a maw station or in a port of call, they are doubtless one of these nomads, roaming without direction in search of a new home.

trait.name: Adaptive Metabolism
entries: The skathári takes no damage from the extreme temperatures of space and other harsh environments (see Appendix E), and it can hold its breath for 30 minutes. Additionally, the skathári has advantage on ability checks and saving throws against inhaled poisons and gases.

trait.name: Gliding Wings
entries: The skathári has a pair of membranous wings that it can use to glide clumsily through the air. When falling, the skathári can move up to 10 feet horizontally for every 5 feet fallen, up to its movement speed. Additionally, the skathári has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage taken as a result of falling.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the skathári can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Regenerative
entries: If any part of the skathári's body is amputated, but its amputation doesn't kill the skathári, it can fully regrow that part of its body in 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The skathári makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Skathári Warclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) obrażeń przebijających.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

Smugglers have a rough, dangerous edge to them, even though they might seem incontrovertibly friendly at first meeting. It's in their nature to keep a blaster held under the table, ready to shoot first, in case the law or some other threatening agent grows wise to the cargo they are smuggling. Though charm is their first line of defense, few smugglers are adverse to a bloody shootout if it means they still get paid.

trait.name: Dodge Roll
entries: As a bonus action, the smuggler can move up to 15 feet. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks, ignores difficult terrain, and can move the smuggler through hostile creature's spaces, as long as it doesn't end its movement there.

trait.name: Quick Draw
entries: The smuggler has advantage on initiative rolls. Additionally, it can draw or stow up to two weapons when it rolls initiative and whenever it takes an action on its turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The smuggler makes two attacks.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 5 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) obrażeń przebijających.

action.name: Magnus
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 70/280 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage. The weapon then overheats, and can't be used until the end of the smuggler's next turn.

action.name: Repeater
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} do trafienia, zasięg 60/240 stóp, jeden cel. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) obrażeń od promieniowania.

reaction.name: Skin of Your Teeth (3/Day)
entries: The smuggler adds 4 ({@dice 1d8}) to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the smuggler must see the attacker.

Long journeys on transport freighters and sojourns on lonely space stations mean that spacers almost never encounter natural gravity. So accustomed are they to life on spacecraft, the hazards of the 'verse become humdrum, and the strange and fearsome creatures they encounter become mundane.

trait.name: Weightlessness Training
entries: In zero gravity, the spacer suffers no penalty to its movement speed while climbing.

action.name: Wrenchinator
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d12 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

Vect juggernauts are heavily armored, and carry large melee weapons such as greataxes, rocket hammers, and mauls. When entering combat, a vect juggernaut usually leads with its embedded battlefist, charging and pummeling its enemies, pursuing all who escape, and leaving a path of destruction in their wake.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the vect moves at least 15 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its battlefist on the same turn, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Construct Anatomy
entries: The vect is immune to nonmagical diseases, and it doesn't need to eat, drink, or breathe.

trait.name: Inflexible Mind
entries: The vect has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vect makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Battlefist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Embedded Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.
Vect scouts specialize in reconnaissance and infiltration. They are fitted with an arm blade and an embedded phaser, and can therefore pass as unarmed at a glance.

trait.name: Construct Anatomy
entries: The vect is immune to nonmagical diseases, and it doesn't need to eat, drink, or breathe.

trait.name: Inflexible Mind
entries: The vect has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The vect has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The vect deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the vect that isn't incapacitated and the vect doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vect makes two attacks with its arm blade or two attacks with its embedded phaser.

action.name: Arm Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Embedded Phaser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) radiant damage.

trait.name: Constructed Nature
entries: You don't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Photon Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} Your spell attack bonus to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage.

monster.name: Mechanized Autonomous Construct
languages: one language of its creator's choice

trait.name: Constructed Nature
entries: The construct doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Combat Protocols
entries: When it rolls initiative, the construct adopts one of two different modes of operation, Offensive or Defensive, which influences the actions it can take in combat.

trait.name: Offensive Mode
entries: While in this mode, attacks against the construct have advantage. The construct can take the Attack (melee weapon attacks only), Dash, Ready, and Use an Object actions on its turn.

trait.name: Defensive Mode
entries: While in this mode, melee attacks against the construct's creator have disadvantage while the attacker is within the construct's reach. The construct can take the Dash, Disengage, Dodge, Help, Hide, and Use an Object actions on its turn.

action.name: Integrated Mace
entries: {@atk mw} its creator's Intelligence modifier + its proficiency bonus to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Impulse Leap
entries: The construct launches itself up to 30 feet in any direction, without provoking opportunity attacks.

optionalfeature.name: Adaptable Omnitool
entries: This gadget can be configured into a number of useful devices, including the following:

entries.name: Auto-Entry Device
entries: This device automatically attempts to crack physical locks or hack powered doors when set to do so as an action. Its ability check for doing so is 10 + your Intelligence modifier.

entries.name: Rebreather
entries: You can start or stop breathing through this apparatus as a bonus action. When doing so, you can breathe normally in airless environments. This device also shelters you from toxic fumes and other airborne poisons. You can't talk while breathing through this device.

entries.name: Scanner
entries: As an action, you can use your handheld scanner to analyze the electromagnetic spectrum around you. Your scanner detects the presence, number, and type of technological devices within 30 feet of you and can determine whether or not a unique construct or device has been present in the area within the last hour.

entries.name: Taser
entries: This device produces a debilitating current of electricity when you use it as an action. Make a melee attack roll (attack bonus equals your Intelligence bonus + your proficiency modifier) against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d8 lightning damage, and it can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. This damage increases to 2d8 lightning damage at when you reach 5th level, 3d8 at 11th level, and 4d8 at 17th level.

optionalfeature.name: Blink Button
entries: This complicated looking device has a single large red button on its face. When you press it as an action, you teleport up to 15 feet to an unoccupied location of your choice that you can see.

optionalfeature.name: Bubble Projector
entries: You construct a device that, as an action, creates a dome of force as if you had cast the spell geodesic shield. You don't need to concentrate on this spell. Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Chronoshifter
entries: When you use your bonus action to activate this sophisticated, spherical device, you temporarily distort time, as per the spell time stop. Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Death Ray
entries: You construct a {@item death ray|darkmatter} magic item.

optionalfeature.name: F-MAC
entries: You integrate a set of thrusters into your construct, granting it a flying speed of 30 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Feedback Electrodes
entries: You've installed an electrical feedback system into your Utility Matrix. When you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to deal {@damage 2d6} lightning damage to that creature.
This damage improves as you gain higher levels in this class. At 11th level, you can deal {@damage 3d6} damage, and at 17th level, you can deal {@damage 4d6} damage.

optionalfeature.name: Flux Cannon
entries: This gadget, which looks like a blaster ending in a series of lenses, modulates the temperature of matter. When you activate it as an action, you can chill or warm a 5-foot cube of nonliving matter within 30 feet that isn't being worn or carried to a temperature you choose. You can heat or freeze most matter to extreme temperatures, resulting in different effects, depending on the material: heating water to its extreme causes it to boil, and chilling it causes it to freeze instantly; heating wood instantly causes it to combust, and freezing causes it to become more brittle; heating metal causes it to glow red-hot and become malleable, and chilling it causes it to become brittle and shrink slightly. At its extreme setting, this device can normally cause a change in its target's state of matter, especially if used on a target for multiple rounds, but the GM decides the exact effects on different materials.

optionalfeature.name: Focus Aperture
entries: The short and long ranges of blasters you use is doubled, up to a maximum of 180/720 feet, or the blaster's original range, whichever is longer.

optionalfeature.name: Gravity Manipulator
entries: This blaster-like device emits a soft glow from the center of its conical muzzle. While holding it, you can activate one of the following effects:

entries.name: Levitate
entries: As an action, you nullify the gravitational forces on a Large or smaller creature or object weighing less than 500 pounds that you can see within 30 feet. The target is attracted to you and comes to rest in a space that you choose within 5 feet of you. You can move the target around you and choose its orientation on your turn. You can levitate a target for 1 minute at a time with this device.

An unwilling creature can make a Constitution saving throw to resist this device's effects and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. The target can move only by pushing or pulling against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling), which allows it to move as if it were climbing.

entries.name: Repel
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can violently repel, in a direction that you choose, a target that is being levitated by this gadget. The target is pushed 60 feet if it is Tiny or Small size, 30 feet if it is Medium, or 15 feet if it is Large. If the target contacts an obstacle, both the target and the obstacle take {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage. If the target's shape permits, it can deal piercing or slashing damage, at the GM's discretion. The target is then no longer levitated by this gadget.

optionalfeature.name: Hologram Projector
entries: When you activate this device as a bonus action, it produces an effect identical to the spell {@spell mirror image|phb}, except that it only creates one illusory duplicate of yourself. This duplicate lasts for 3 rounds, then dissipates. This is not a magical effect, doesn't require your concentration, and can't be dispelled with dispel magic or similar effects.

entries.name: Upgrade (17th level)
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: You gain two illusory duplicates, rather than one, when you use this gadget.

optionalfeature.name: Hypnosis Ray
entries: This phaser-like device fires harmless swirls of colors to mesmerize a humanoid creature within 30 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be charmed by you for up to 1 minute. While charmed, the target is incapacitated and its speed is 0. This effect ends early if the creature takes damage or if you use this device again. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to this gadget for 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Invisibomb
entries: When you activate this device as an action and throw it to a space within 30 feet, it produces a faint shimmer, and then each creature within 60 feet of it vanishes from sight. Each creature within that radius becomes invisible, as per invisibility, for a number of rounds equal to your Intelligence modifier. Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Jetpack
entries: You construct a {@item jetpack|darkmatter} magic item.

entries.name: Upgrade (13th level)
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: You can use this magic item for an unlimited amount of time each day.

optionalfeature.name: Jump Pad
entries: When you deploy this rectangular device as an action, it unfolds into a 5-foot square panel that whirs with an upward thrust. Whenever a creature moves atop the panel, they are launched up to 30 feet in any direction they choose. The creature takes no falling damage for the first 30 feet it falls. The jump pad deactivates after 1 minute or when you collect it on your turn (no action required.)

optionalfeature.name: Magnet Boots
entries: These weighty boots grant you the ability to move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings, while leaving your hands free. You also gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

optionalfeature.name: Mega-Gizmo
entries: You can use two of your Utility Matrix's devices as a bonus action. These devices must each activate as a bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Micro-Missile
entries: As an action, this wrist-mounted device fires a small homing missile at a target you can see within 30 feet. This missile automatically hits its target and deals {@damage 1d6} force damage. You fire additional missiles when you reach higher levels in this class: 2 missiles at 5th level, 3 missiles at 11th level, and 4 missiles at 17th level. You can direct the missiles at the same target or at different ones.

optionalfeature.name: Micro-Turret
entries: As an action, this device can be thrown to any unoccupied space within 10 feet of you, where it transforms into a Small stationary blaster turret, which has AC 10 and 30 HP. Reducing the turret to 0 hit points disables it.

The turret makes a ranged attack roll (attack bonus equals your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier) against a creature you designate within 60 feet of it. On a hit, the turret deals {@damage 1d8} radiant damage. You can use your bonus action on subsequent turns to designate a target for the turret and command it to attack. After 1 minute, the turret deactivates and must charge for 1 minute before being deployed again.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: When you command the turret to fire, you can choose for it to fire an overcharged shot, which deals {@damage 3d8} radiant damage on a hit. The turret then overheats, and can't be used to fire on the following turn.

optionalfeature.name: Molecular Destablizer
entries: As an action, you can activate this gadget, which looks like a blaster with a widely-flared muzzle. When you do so, it disintegrates a nonliving object you choose within 5 feet of you that can fit entirely within a 3-foot cube, reducing it into a fine dust. This gadget has no effect on metallic objects or magic items.

optionalfeature.name: Motion Tracker
entries: You construct a {@item motion tracker|darkmatter} magic item.

optionalfeature.name: Omni-Grenade
entries: As an action, you can prime this device to release a blast of elemental energy and throw it up to 30 feet. You can collect and reuse the device after it is thrown. When you prime the grenade, choose one of the following effects:

entries.name: Fire
entries: The grenade explodes in a scorching inferno. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d8} fire damage and an additional {@damage 2d8} fire damage at the beginning of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and none at the beginning of its next turn.

entries.name: Ice
entries: The grenade explodes with a cryogenic blast of frigid air. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d8} cold damage and its speed is halved until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and its speed isn't halved.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: The grenade explodes in a crackling electric burst. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d8} lightning damage and can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and can still take reactions.

This gadget improves as you gain levels in this class. At 11th level, you deal an additional {@damage 1d8} damage when a target fails its saving throw against your grenade, and at 17th level, you deal an additional {@damage 2d8} damage.

optionalfeature.name: Orbital Superweapon
entries: You have pieced together a massive doomsday device, an orbital cannon, which you store in a pocket dimension for convenience. By throwing out a beacon, you can summon the weapon and fire it, as per the spell {@spell orbital hardlight cannon|darkmatter}. You don't need to concentrate on this spell. Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Overheat Beacon
entries: As an action, you can activate this gadget, which produces a signal that causes every blaster within 60 feet to overheat. An overheated weapon can't be used to make an attack again until the end of your next turn. Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again for 1 minute.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: When you activate this gadget, you can choose any number of blasters within range to be unaffected by it.

optionalfeature.name: R-MAC
entries: You reinforce your MAC with high-density alloy bands. As a result, the construct has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons.

optionalfeature.name: Remote Gloves
entries: These rocket-powered robotic gauntlets fly around following your every gesture. You can deploy the gauntlets or retrieve them as a bonus action. On each of your turns, without using an action, you can command each of the gauntlets to move up to 30 feet. The gauntlets will automatically stay within 30 feet of you, as they become inactive if they ever fall outside of this range.

You can assume control of the gauntlets to perform actions at a distance. When you do so, the gauntlets exactly mimic your hands, allowing you to manipulate objects and technological devices, store and retrieve items, or perform any other action for which you normally use your hands. Controlling each gauntlet requires a free hand and takes actions to perform tasks as if you were performing them yourself.
The gauntlets can't attack, activate magic items or gadgets, or carry more than 25 pounds each.

optionalfeature.name: Ricochet Aperture
entries: Your weapon attacks using blasters ignore half and three- quarters cover, if there exists a solid surface off of which to ricochet the shot towards the target. You can target a creature in total cover with a ricocheted blaster attack with disadvantage if you know the target's location within 5 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Rocket Fists
entries: You have replaced your frame's hands with rocket fists. The fists are ranged weapons with a range of 60/180, which use your Intelligence modifier for attack and damage rolls. On a hit, a fist deals {@damage 1d10} bludgeoning damage. When you make a melee weapon attack with an integrated weapon or a ranged attack with a rocket fist, you can make an additional ranged attack with a rocket fist as a bonus action. A launched rocket fist returns to you at the end of your turn.

optionalfeature.name: Self-Destruct Sequence
entries: You've installed an explosive mechanism into your frame, allowing you to detonate it when you enter a special code as an action. When you enter the self-destruct code into your frame, you can specify that it detonates after 1 round, 3 rounds, or 10 rounds (1 minute). You can deactivate the self-destruct code as an action. The frame explodes in a 60-foot radius, destroying it completely. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 14d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. You can rebuild the frame with one week of work.

optionalfeature.name: Shrink Ray
entries: As an action while holding this device, you can target a creature within 30 feet with the Reduce effect of the {@spell enlarge/reduce|phb} spell. This effect doesn't require your concentration and can't be dispelled with dispel magic or similar effects. Only one target can be affected by this gadget at a time.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: You can use the Enlarge option of the enlarge/reduce spell when you use this device.

optionalfeature.name: Sonic Amplifier
entries: This device, which is fitted with several large speakers on its face, can deaden or amplify sounds within range. When you activate the device as an action, choose one of the following effects:

entries.name: Anti-Sound
entries: A 20-foot radius sphere around you is rendered completely silent until the beginning of your next turn. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are deafened while entirely inside it. Casting a spell that includes a verbal component is impossible within the area.

entries.name: Noise Burst
entries: The amplifier creates a sudden blast of white noise. Each creature you choose within 20 feet of you must make a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} thunder damage. This damage increases to {@damage 2d6} thunder damage at when you reach 5th level, {@damage 3d6} at 11th level, and {@damage 4d6} at 17th level.

optionalfeature.name: Spectrum Visor
entries: This visor has a single long slit, blipping with lights and sensors. As an action or bonus action, you can activate one of the following visor modes. Only one visor mode can be active at a time.

entries.name: Aurasight
entries: You can see a faint aura around any visible creature or object within 30 feet that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any. This detection can penetrate most barriers, but is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You gain {@sense darkvision}, which means you can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Thermalsight
entries: You gain {@sense thermalsight|DarkMatter}, which means you can see living creatures through darkness and heavily obscured conditions, such as fog, out to a range of 30 feet. You can also determine if a creature is living or dead though its body heat. However, you can't discern color, nor use this sense to see through illusions, invisibility, or magical darkness. This sense is blocked by one inch of any solid barrier.

optionalfeature.name: Spell Cube
entries: As a reaction when a spell of 1st to 5th level that would affect you is cast, you can trap it within the spell cube. The spell has no effect and is instead contained within the cube. The cube can only store one spell at a time.

While holding the cube, you can cast the spell stored in it, expending it. The spell uses the slot level, spell save DC, spell attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the original caster, but is otherwise treated as if you cast the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Stasis Field Generator
entries: This device deploys a 5-foot diameter spherical forcefield around you as a reaction when you drop to 0 hit points. Until the beginning of your next turn, you are enveloped within this forcefield, which nothing—not physical objects, energy, or spell effects—can penetrate. The forcefield itself is immune to damage and you can't be damaged further while within the sphere, nor do you make death saving throws. The sphere is weightless and can be moved while you're within it. At the beginning of your next turn, the sphere deactivates, and you are restored to consciousness with 1 hit point. Once this device activates, it can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: You can activate this gadget as a bonus action on your turn, placing you in the spherical forcefield and restoring 1 of your hit points.

optionalfeature.name: Tesla Mines
entries: You gain a set of three electrical proximity mines. As an action, you can activate and throw a mine onto a surface within 40 feet, to which it firmly attaches. If a creature other than yourself enters the 5-foot cube area originating at the top of the mine, it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 2d8} lightning damage and can't move or take reactions until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half this amount of damage and can move and take reactions as normal.
You can disarm and recover a mine within 5 feet of you as an action. After 1 hour, a deployed mine burns out. You rebuild deployed and burned out mines during a long rest.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This gadget can be chosen twice, gaining the following upgrade when you select it the second time: A mine triggers when a creature enters a 15-foot cube originating at the top of the mine.

optionalfeature.name: Transmat Deck
entries: You construct a {@item transmat deck|darkmatter} magic item.

optionalfeature.name: Universal Translator
entries: You construct a {@item universal translator|darkmatter} magic item and can also use it to read all writing.

optionalfeature.name: Version 1812 Multirocket Launcher
entries: As an action, this device unfolds into a comically large multi-barrel rocket launcher, which proceeds to fire wildly in every direction while playing a grand overture. Each creature other than yourself within 30 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 6d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.
Once you use this gadget, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Zipgun
entries: You build a {@item zipgun|darkmatter} magic item. This magic item's save DC equals your Gadget save DC. Once this item burns out, you can rebuild it during a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Akimbo
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting with blasters, you do not take a penalty to the damage of the second attack.

optionalfeature.name: Crippling
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, to a minimum of 0, until the end of its next turn and it can't take the {@action Dash} action until the end of its turn.

optionalfeature.name: Duelist
entries: While you are wielding a blaster in one hand and nothing in the other, if you make a ranged weapon attack and exceed the target's AC by 5 or more, you deal an additional die of weapon damage. You can only use this ability once per round.

optionalfeature.name: Shotgunner
entries: When you hit with a ranged weapon attack using a blaster that has the Scatter property, you can reroll the lowest damage die, and you must use the new roll, even if the new roll is worse than the original.

optionalfeature.name: Titan Fighting
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to melee weapon attack rolls you make against Large or larger creatures.

optionalfeature.name: Directed Momentum
entries: Once on each of your turns, when you score a critical hit with a melee attack or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with one, you can make an unarmed strike against a second target. If the target is within range of your Shock Trooper feature, you can lunge toward it. On a hit, this attack deals an additional {@damage 1d8} force damage.

optionalfeature.name: Encryptogram
entries: Your knowledge of ciphers has improved your magically clandestine communications. When you cast the {@spell cryptogram|darkmatter} cantrip, its limit is 20 characters, instead of 8, and only the specified recipient can read the message.

optionalfeature.name: Gauntlet Upgrade
entries: You install a high-power module in your blaster gauntlet. You can apply one of the following two modifiers to cantrips that you cast using your Coalition Blaster Gauntlet ability.

entries.name: Beam
entries: The cantrip creates a 5-foot wide beam out to the spell's range in a direction you choose. This beam lasts until the start of your next turn. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or take the spell's damage.

entries.name: Overheat
entries: The cantrip's damage dice become d12s.
Once you use one of these modifiers, you can't use them again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Leading Edge Tactics
entries: You always have a plan when engaging the enemy. As such, attacks during the first round of combat have disadvantage against you.

optionalfeature.name: Technomancer
entries: Your constant exposure to magical technology has given you the ability to manipulate it almost subconsciously. You can cast the cantrip {@spell technomancy|darkmatter} as a bonus action on your turn, and can do so without using somatic components. Additionally, you can use the cantrip to attempt to hack devices within range.

race.name: Amoeboid
entries: As an amoeboid, your bizarre anatomy grants you the following racial traits:

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Intelligence score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: Amoeboids swiftly reach maturity, growing to full size in a mere 3 years, and have especially long lifespans, living as long as 200 to 300 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Natural-born scientists, amoeboids tend to be skeptical and deductive. They lean toward neutral alignments.

entries.name: Size
entries: Amoeboids have a roughly similar mass to other humanoid creatures and stand 4 to 5 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Flexible Form
entries: You can use your action to stretch, compress, and mold your body into a myriad of shapes. You can transform into any static form that you choose that is no larger than 8 feet in any dimension. When you assume this form, you can replicate something's basic shape but not its color, texture, moving parts, or fine details. You can't change your body's volume, nor can you move, attack, or cast spells while you're transformed into a static shape.

You can also use your action to touch a living creature and assume its general form. Your size and other statistics don't change. You gain the ability to speak and understand that creature's language, and if the target has a burrowing, climbing, or swimming speed, you gain those with the same speed, up to a maximum of 40 feet.

Your transformation ends after 1 hour, or when you choose to end it on your turn (no action required). If you transform into a form incapable of wearing armor, your armor falls off. You can only take actions while you're transformed if you are in the form of a creature, and you can only take actions that creature would be able to take.

entries.name: Amorphous
entries: You can compress your body enough to squeeze through a 1-inch wide space. You can't expand inside a space that offers any resistance.

entries.name: Reform
entries: Whenever you take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from a nonmagical weapon and don't drop to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to immediately regain {@dice 1d4} hit points, up to a maximum of the amount of damage taken.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Amoeboid. Most creatures are only able to approximate speaking Amoeboid, for its burbling words are made using the amoeboid's fluid body. If you are transformed into a creature that has a language, you can speak and understand that language.

fluff.name: Amoeboid

entries: "Another failed experiment," muttered Yr. The amoeboid's nucleus flashed dark red, his version of a resigned sigh. Standing in the medical bay of his saucer, he watched a pair of automatons clean viscera off the walls and ceiling.

"The serum made no difference; those cows were just like the last batch," said Yr, making a gesture like stroking his chin. He made his way to the next room, where a terrified human man lay restrained on a table, yelling incoherently. He touched the man and his shape changed, taking on more human-like proportions, but with a grossly overlarge head and bulging eyes.

"Sorry for the inconvenience," Yr apologized in the man's language. "I wish I could repay you for your livestock, but we have rules against that sort of thing, I'm afraid. Now please stop squirming while I ready a memory modification."
entries.by: Yr, amoeboid scientist, assessing a Void experiment

entries: Amoeboids are intelligent, vaguely humanoid-shaped, translucent oozes that can mimic the form of any creature they touch. These creatures tend to the maw stations, experimenting into the nature of space and time, parlaying with any creature they meet.

entries.name: Fluid Anatomy
entries: Amoeboid bodies are almost entirely composed of a translucent jelly-like substance, with a complex network of nerves visible throughout, which emit a dim blue light. Within their heads, a large, brain-like nucleus floats, surrounded by five eyespots spaced radially around it.

Their fluid bodies can take the genetic imprint of creatures they touch, molding into an inexact copy, visibly made of the same jelly material. When in this form, however, amoeboids can speak the language of their copy and move in much the same way, allowing them to empathize with virtually any creature.

No one is sure exactly how the bizarre anatomy of the amoeboids came to be, for they are among the oldest races in the 'verse and few accounts exist before them. The elves believe that their strange forms were created  on a rogue world, flung into the Black by a catastrophic event, but the avia-ra maintain that their forms are a result of long-term corruption by the Void. There might be some credence to this latter theory, for those that are exposed to the Void's terrible lights and survive undergo the warp and are changed in drastic and horrifying ways, being robbed forever of their previous forms. Perhaps, it is possible that the amoeboids were warped so intensely they were left as mere genetic sludge, lacking any true shape.

entries.name: Scientists and Mawkeepers
entries: Above all else, amoeboids value logical thinking as a lens to analyze the world. They keenly believe that the multiverse is founded on an objective, concrete reality defined solely by magic and physics, all of which can be understood. All things, including the elusive mystery of the maw stations, can be unraveled with proper attention, experimentation, and reasoning. Most amoeboids regard no subject as taboo and have few qualms about any kind of research, as long as its methodology is sound and is reasonably likely to produce useful data.

Most amoeboids live on the maw stations themselves, researching the maw's activities, repairing ships and {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter engines}, and trading information with other scientists and wizards the 'verse over. With their keen intellect, amoeboids make excellent alchemists, gadgeteers, and wizards, and can find no better place to live than the maw stations.

entries.name: Strange Visitors
entries: Amoeboids have taken to visiting settled worlds in secret, disguising their saucers and themselves to perform experiments on the inhabitants. By and large, these experiments are noninvasive, but are nonetheless unwelcome. As a result, many worlds have ancient tales of strange visitors from the stars, looking much like them, but strangely distorted, who steal individuals away by night and subject them to strange rituals in brightly lit rooms. Amoeboids will also vivisect the odd head of livestock, but these occurrences are more likely to be blamed on predators than on men from the stars.

Ever concerned with efficiency, amoeboid names can traditionally be represented by a single unusual character, to differentiate it from the rest of a particular alphabet. Amoeboids don't differentiate between males and females, nor are their names particularly masculine or feminine.

entries.name: Amoeboid Names
entries: Ash (Æ), Chevron (Λ), Digamma (Ͷ), Eth (Ð), Ezh (Ʒ), Gangia (Ϫ), Kai (ϗ), Pilcrow (¶), Psi (Ψ), Shei (Ϣ), Solidus (/), Thorn (Þ), Tilde (~), Yr (Ʀ)

race.name: Avia-Ra
entries: Though different avia-ra families may have different bird heads, all avia-ra have the following racial traits:

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: Avia-Ra are long lived, and due to their long lives, they have been revered as gods by more primitive beings. They reach maturity at roughly 30 years of age, and can live as long as 500 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The avia-ra draw their morality and philosophy from the sun. Though this solar religion can be severe, fatalistic, and dogmatic, most avia-ra have an inclination towards good—or at least lawful—alignments.

entries.name: Size
entries: Avia-Ra stand between 5 and 6 feet in height, and weigh roughly 120 to 170 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: You have a base walking speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to the rituals of your ancestors, the light of the sun dances in your eyes and grants you superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Avia-Ra Weapon Training
entries: You have proficiency with the avia-ra {@item sunstaff|darkmatter}, {@item scimitar|phb}, {@item shortbow|phb}, {@item spear|phb}, and {@item whip|phb}.

entries.name: Doctrine
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Religion} skill.

entries.name: Blessings of the Sun
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell bless|phb}, targeting only yourself, without using a spell slot. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell. For the spell's duration, if you roll a 4 on the d4 that you add to an attack roll or saving throw, you gain advantage on that attack roll or saving throw.
Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Sun's Chosen
entries: You know the {@spell sacred flame|phb} and {@spell thaumaturgy|phb} cantrips. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Avia-Ra. Avia-Ra is a language filled with soft consonants and long vowel sounds. Its written form uses the Celestial script.

fluff.name: Avia-Ra

entries: Upon the Black and Night Crusade, Rode the fearless, heroes they. Citadel, unto their grasp, Fleets adjoined; O' pilgrim's wrath. Prostrate 'fore the Sun Above, All to arms–never love.
The avia-ra are a sun-worshipping race of wingless birdmen, which appear to primitive cultures to spread their ancient religion.

entries.name: Ancient God-Kings
entries: Depictions of the avia-ra can be found in the ruins of ancient cultures throughout the galaxy. Often, but not always, they are portrayed as divinity manifest: god-like travelers from the heavens. They arrive as evangelists to share the philosophy of their solar religion—that the Sun Above is the only true god—and remain long enough to build an enduring civilization on the primitive world.

Some races consider the avia-ra an ancient and wise people, dedicated to their religion and its tenets. Others cast them as charlatans and false prophets, who routinely prey upon primitive and defenseless peoples. The truth depends largely on perspective, but the avia-ra view themselves only as a grand tool to carry the momentum of the sun's glory to new peoples.
